title: Paper City Uprising
outcome: With Tribunal records lost, Stenograd’s digital infrastructure remains offline. Grassroots networks organize on paper and in-person councils, competing with Directorate loyalists trying to restore digital order. As popular distrust in centralized control grows, a citywide analog referendum is called. The city finds unity and division as it prepares to decide its governance, with echoes of Halden's ideals shaping the struggle.

events.description: Grassroots councils take over public spaces, distributing independent paper ration cards and convening town meetings. Trust shifts from digital to face-to-face collective decisions.
Directorate loyalists make a push to quietly restart BCI scoring, but local leaders intercept attempts and rally neighborhoods against a return to digital control.
The Council, fracturing under pressure, announces a citywide analog referendum. Ballots are distributed for residents to decide on permanent localized governance or the return of central authority.

In-person debates fill squares and halls as citizens argue over future leadership. Old divisions resurface, but new alliances form around shared memory and Halden’s early warnings about unchecked system power.

The referendum results are announced: a slim majority votes for decentralized, neighborhood-based councils. The city celebrates and mourns, knowing Stenograd's future is both uncertain and in its own hands.
